बेरोजगार लोग एक बार जरूर पढ़े।
घर बैठे Online Work करें और
10000 से 15,000 रूपये हर महीने कमाये वो
भी कुछ खर्च किये बिना।
आपके पास Android Mobile होना जरुरी है। आपको क्या लगता है हम झुठ बोल रहे है?

तो जाने आप सब अपने ही Android मोबाइल से कैसे पैसे कमा सकते है।

इसके लिए सबसे पहले Champcash पर एक ID बनाना जरूरी है। Champcash पर ID बनाने के कुछ STEPS है जो निम्न है:-

1st STEP:
अपने फ़ोन के Play Store में जायें और Search में "Champcash Digital India App" लिखें और उस App को अपने मोबाइल में Install कर लें !

2nd STEP:
अब Sign Up with Champcash पर Click करके अपनी डिटेल्स (Name, Mobile No, Email Id) डाल दीजिये।
[Note: Apna WhyatsApp No hi Register kare]

3rd STEP:
अब आपसे Refer ID of Sponsor पूछा जायेगा वहाँ पर 18966060 डाल दें और अपनी ID बना लें!

4th STEP:
अब आपको स्क्रीन पर Challenge ऐप्स के रूप में 7-8 ऐप्स दिखेगा जिसमें से 5-6 ऐप्स Install करने के लिए कहा जायेगा। इन ऐप्स को इंस्टॉल किए बगैर आप इसमें ज्वाइन नहीं हो सकते !

5th STEP:
सभी ऐप्स (5-6 ऐप्स) को एक-एक करके इनस्टॉल और रजिस्टर करना है। प्रत्येक ऐप्प पर रेजिस्ट्रेशन के बाद Open करना है और 2-3 मिनट Open रखना है।

Champcash मे आपकी ID Active होते ही स्क्रीन पर Congratulations! का मैसेज आयेगा और आपके Champcash एकाउंट में $1=62 Rs. आ जायेगा। एक बार आपकी ID Active हो जाने के बाद आप चाहे तो Install किये हुए सारे ऐप्स(5-6 ऐप्स) Uninstall भी कर सकते हैं।

जैसे ही आपकी ID Active होगी, हमारी Team आप से जल्द सम्पर्क करेगी।

*निम्न 2 बातों का ध्यान रखें* :-
[A] आप जिस मोबाइल में Champcash Install कर रहें उस मोबाइल का ही Internet इस्तेमाल करें।
[B] एक मोबाइल में एक ही Champcash ID बनाया जा सकता है।
मैं आपको बिस्वास दिलाता हूँ कि ये कोई Fake कंपनी नही है। for Enquiry call my no. 9617974592 at9:30pm to 11:00pm

This event is being organized as an institute lecture. This is a special lecture as this is the celebration of the 150th birth anniversary of Sister Nivedita. This has relevance to the women empowerment, freedom movement and science movement of our country.

Discourse by Pravrajika Atandraprana, Asst. General Secretary, Sri Sarada Math & Ramakrishna Sarada Mission

Time: 5:30 PM

“Ask the right questions, and nature will open the doors to her secrets”

A precocious and gifted student, Sir C V Raman, passed his matriculation at 11 and his F.A., with a scholarship, at 13. A Gold Medal for a Bachelors in Physics at the Presidency University Madras was followed by a Master of Sciences with the highest distinction.

Pursuit of the sciences brought him to academia in KOLKATA and thus began what he would fondly refer to as the golden era of his career. He continued his research at the Indian Association for the Cultivation of Sciences (IACS) of which he was also the Honorary secretary. It was IACS that Raman led experiments, along with K S Krishnan, on the scattering of light, and discovering what came to be known as the Raman effect.

This discovery of immense importance soon garnered him recognition and fame and plaudits of the scientific community all over the world including enthusiastic mentions by the ‘father of nuclear physics’ Ernest Rutherford. He was soon conferred a knighthood and numerous awards. In receiving the Nobel Prize for #physics in 1930 he became the first Asian and non-european to receive the Nobel in the sciences.

#CVRaman had and continues to spark the imagination of the scientific community of India till this day. He was born #OTD in 1888. We honour him with a glimpse of his life and works sourced from the Raman Research Institute: http://bit.ly/2AaMPTu

#Tribute #Birthday #NuclearPhysics #Stalwart #LearnShareGrow

Researchers at IIT Kharagpur have developed a new Smartphone App, SmartIHC-Analyser, which can help in faster and more accurate evaluation of cancer after treatment. The App analyses the expression of a protein marker (Ki-67) for determining an increase in cancer cells.
The smartphone is fitted to the eye-piece of the microscope using a specially designed 3D-printed holder to take microscopic images of the cancer cells. To analyse proliferation, the colour variations in the stained cancer cells are studied.
The researchers analysed 30 cases of Ki-67-stained breast cancer tissues collected from Tata Medical Center, Kolkata (which collaborated in the study) and compared the results from the app with manual counting. Compared with the manual method, the app had nearly 97% accuracy.

Source: http://www.thehindu.com/s...

In order to boost the entrepreneurship initiative at IIT-KGP and enable technological knowledge exchange, IIT Kharagpur and Pepperdine University (US) have joined hands. Pepperdine is globally known for its venture capital-backed entrepreneurial ventures, would collaborate for technological knowledge exchange with IIT Kharagpur. Referring to the latest PitchBook report on top universities producing VC-backed entrepreneurs, workshop faculty member, and coordinator of the programme Dr. P K Dan said, "Pepperdine MBA ranks 25th where universities like Harvard, MIT, Stanford, INSEAD or Carnegie Mellon are also listed and such collaborative initiatives will benefit our students.". Our Honourable Director Partha Pratim Chakrabarti recently met the US-based team and urged the group to prepare a roadmap for continued collaborative activities. The faculty at Pepperdine, Prof. Larry Cox recently visited IIT KGP and conducted a workshop on Entrepreneurship Promotion along with his associates at Entrepreneur Institute Inc, where he is the Chief Education Officer. They imparted training on increasing creative capacity and the creative problem-solving process.
The workshop was jointly held with the Rajendra Mishra School of Engineering Entrepreneurship (RMSoEE) at IIT Kharagpur and the upcoming Research Park of IIT Kharagpur in Kolkata. It focused on product engineering, reverse-forward engineering, and rapid prototyping.
Professor Larry Cox said, "Pepperdine University's Graziadio School of Business and Management is very pleased to be collaborating with RMSoEE, IIT Kharagpur to strengthen both our educational offerings with regard to technology entrepreneurship."
Source- http://indiatoday.intoday...

The Students’ Senate has finally devised a solution to overcome the inconvenience caused due to the park space crunch in the LHCs, halls of residence and practically everywhere for quite some time now. And they have come through in fine fashion. Their idea of a cycle pool got its wings when OLA took the initiative to make one in the campus.
The OLA cycle pool services (OLA Pedal) will see a trial period of a month or two first. Renting these cycles is also made hassle free as it would be similar to booking an OLA ride through the app. You enter a code, unique for each cycle, and the combination for the lock would be provided to you. And after you are done, you can drop it off to an OLA parking nearest to your destination, notify the app and the fares would be as per the following, for the trial period: free for the first 30 minutes (per ride), and then Rs.5 per 30 minutes.
The second phase would have much more sophisticated cycles, with a GPS, QR codes, smart locks, instead of the ones they have now, better security features to keep the cycles within the campus and much more. The campus will have around 400-600 of these cycles by the end of this week to be dispatched for public use with around 250 of them within the week. With this innovative solution, we surely will have one less thing to worry about. Happy cycling!
Credits : Aditya Jain

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 6 new photos.
message:
The much awaited collaboration between IIT Kharagpur and YourDost has finally turned into reality. All the current students can set up their accounts on the website (https://yourdost.com) and get all kind of assistance that they are looking for in their hard times. Accounts can be set up (for free) using only KGP LAN and WiFi. However, once registered, you can use the services anywhere and anytime.
On 31st October, the official launching ceremony was held at S.N. Bose auditorium. The event was attended by Mr. Puneet Manuja, Co-founder of YourDost, along with renowned psychologist Dr.Gini. But the participation from the student community was not so encouraging in number as there were hardly 40-50 students present there. Firstly, Mr. Puneet made the audience familiar with the online portal and services of YourDOST. He also added that this 24 x 7 active Counseling Center can be used free of cost only after you have registered through the institute network once. Later, the head psychologist of the YourDOST enlightened us about the basic terminologies and symptoms of mental health and illness. In the end of this interactive session, he earnestly suggested everyone to remove the stigma of visiting a psychologist for the help.
You can go through this PDF as well for some insights on mental health: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Y2WVb946Ykvzzsq1oeF_usHtOiTbXT63/view?usp=sharing

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 2 new photos.
message:
Keeping in mind the recent happenings in IIT Kharagpur, a bonfire was arranged in Azad hall as a celebration of the successful completion of their Soc-Cult night. Students took an oath against fire enunciating the importance of togetherness and helpfulness. They also went ahead saying that these Soc-Cult and bonfire nights would be a part of Azad hall culture for the years to come. The oath was written by Ashutosh Bhaskar, a boarder of the hall.

Another purpose of this night was to distribute the prizes to the winners of the So-Cult night. The gold-winning team was awarded Zebronics music system while other two were given a coffee maker. All those winning in any individual event were presented a keyboard.

The Scholars' Avenue encourages such efforts to promote bonding and hopes this occasion would serve as a start to many more so all over the campus.

IIT Kharagpur is proud to have received the great opportunity of conducting the prestigious business model competition, the Hult Prize, in the campus on the November 5th.

Annually organized by the Clint Global Initiative and Hult International Business School, the Hult Prize aims at tackling the serious social problems in the world through business innovation and startup ideas. The challenge for 2018 is to "harness the power of energy to transform the lives of 10 million people."
Teams from IIT Kharagpur have previously been to the regional finals held in Shanghai and London. According to the Campus Director of Hult Prize in IIT Kharagpur, Mr. Shahswat Gangwal, IIT KGP has always considered the international platform provided by the Hult as a great opportunity and has participated in the challenge enthusiastically and with great zeal.
To aid Team KGP, this year too, the organizers have requested the guidance of eminent personalities, Mr. Nagraj Prakasam (Acumen), Mr. Ajay Mutereja and Mr. Md. Saif(EI) to name a few.
Taking the advantage of the immense human resources, knowledge and a great international community, the Hult Prize has always helped the launch of social enterprises which shaped the lives of millions and stood as a prominent student revolution for the transformation of the society.

Yet again IIT KGP proved its excellence in the field of research by inventing a smart polymeric material that can fix car scratches and dents by simply heating the damaged area if it is coated with acrylic polymer named PHEMA-indole-TAD. It has been developed by a research team led by Prof. Singha at the institute’s Centre for Rubber Technology. The institute is going to make this solution commercial in collaboration with companies like ASIAN PAINTS and PIDILITE.
Source- https://economictimes.ind...

Prof. Manoj Tiwari, a professor at the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering has been selected as the first recipient of the Prof. P. C. Mahalanobis Distinguished Educator Award for Management in the year 2017 by the Operational Research Society of India.

Prof. Tiwari joined the institute in the year 2007 as an Associate Professor. He completed his Ph.D. from the Department of Production Engineering, University of Jadavpur. He has been a recipient of various awards and honours which includes Fellow of National Academy of Engineering, India (Effect from 2013), placed at the 14th position in the world’s top 20 most productive authors in five leading POM journals (1959-2008), and 9th position in the world’s top 10 most productive authors in the last decade (1999-2008), rated as Rank 1 among top 100 individual researchers across the world, who had published research articles in International Journal of Production Research (Taylor and Francis) during the time period 1985-2010.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur heartily congratulates our professor for this feat and wishes him all the best for future endeavours!

The marking scheme of the Problem Statement has been circulated to the General Secretary, Technology of all the halls.
Contact them for further information.

Here is the mail that has been sent by Mayank Srivastava, VP, TSG to the KGPians regarding the action plan.

_______________
Hello All,

First of all, thank you for showing the level of concern for the institute and being the part of the Open House session. I have personally thanked our Director, IIT Kharagpur for being the part of the Open House session till the end and helping us resolve all the facts.

We had several meetings with different stakeholders to have an immediate action plan for our problems and prepared a thorough list of solutions. The attached action plan contains the suggestions of ours and the Director. I have tried to give few insights in each of the step giving you more clarity on the same.

ACTION ITEMS

The following points are references to the pdf attached. Kindly go through following points after going through pdf.

1) As asked by few students in the Open House session, the Director has agreed for the external inquiry to be set up. He has himself talked to a retired judge of High Court for the same. However, on expressing concern from our side regarding the problems students involved in the event may face, the Director assured by saying that it will be tried to reduce the friction as much as possible.
2) For the medical audit of BCRTH an expert committee will be appointed in 15 days, panel which would consist of about 2 male and 1 female doctor. We are expecting the audit to be done by the end of December.
3) A complain portal with a complain escalation mechanism is being prepared. The basic feature of the complain portal will be prepared by us which would then be reviewed and improvised by the B C Roy Technology authorities. We are expecting the portal to be implemented by next week.
4) Digitalization of B C Roy Hospital: We have proposed to make all the process of a normal visit of a student to BCRTH digitalized. This will include taking an appointment online, making a student's profile containing all the details of previous visits. Digitalization will remove all the ledger related work and will involve the least paper work. We are also trying to incorporate this in ERP helping students in a systematic approach towards the health issues. It will take about 3 months for the finalization.
5) BCRTH has been stocked with certain life-saving items like anti-venom, anti-rabies etc and other items like clothes to be reviewed in one week. It has been done to equip the hospital 24*7 prepared to tackle few emergency issues.
6) Regarding the public statement from the Institute, the Director has shared the Open House video from his personal Facebook page.
7) We are taking a lot of initiatives by conducting several events for mental well being and also training G Sec Student Welfare Council, TSG and Student Welfare Group. For the same, an annual calendar list will be prepared and will be followed every year.
8) A Dean's Council is being formed to assist Dean, SA and to tackle more student affairs.
9) For a better fire emergency solutions, a plan is being developed by the security to have fire drill and checking the quality of extinguishers.
10) One Annual Health Checkup (not mandatory) whose expenses will be integrated with medical insurances.
11) Tie-ups with Railway hospitals are being made to handle more cases locally.
12) A framework will be planned by December to develop a regulatory mechanism to assess the performance of BCRTH and Counselling Centre throughout the year.
13) One Extra Academic Activity to be incorporated in already existing EAA system, National Cultural Organization. Technology Students' Gymkhana in association with SANDHI and Happiness Centre will be working on the same.

Status of ongoing action items have also been listed in the pdf. I urge you all to stay concerned about the progress of these points as they are of dire need, I will be more than happy to update you about any further development (ping me anytime). As I have stated in my earlier mail also that we, as a student community is also at fault somewhere as you can observe lack of interaction between seniors and even batch-mates, we need to revive our culture which is the core of our development and for the same I will communicate feasible action plan soon. I will try my level best to implement further suggestions and new initiatives towards better KGP.
___________________

With this, a pdf file stating the action plan signed by the director has been shared in the mail as attachment. The pdf can be found here: https://drive.google.com/...

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 7 new photos — with Arhat Ambedkar and 5 others.
message:
The students of IIT Kharagpur made us proud again with their remarkable success at Spardha-2017, IIT BHU’s Annual Sports Fest and the largest inter-collegiate sporting event of India. Our students participated in 6 events out of which KGP won many teams and individual medals, making their presence felt throughout this grand event.

Spardha-2017 Results:

Volleyball
Both Men’s and Women’s team won Bronze medals in the event. Men’s team shot their opponents down in qualifying matches. They gave a tough fight to IIT Kanpur in semifinals
but lost the game in the final set with 15-13 with sets 3-2. Women’s team also showcased their talent by making it to semifinals against NIT Kurukshetra. Losing that, they ended with the Bronze medal.

Weightlifting
KGP bagged Silver with a sum total of 20 points. IIT BHU stood first with 22 points. Besides, numerous individual medals came into our basket:

Under 62 Kg: Bronze- Breety Sundar Mushahary
Under 69 Kg: Gold- सवाई देवपाल; Silver- Vrajesh Nandha
Under 77 Kg: Silver- Arhat Ambedkar; Bronze- Nikhil Tailor
Open Category: Silver- Sandeep Muzzalda; Bronze- Manuveeran Singh Sandhu

Football
Football team secured Bronze with thrashing their opponents SRMCEM down in their last match with a final score of 5-0. Chetan, Pankaj, Dhananjay, Rizeen scored goals for our team in this match.

Badminton
Men’s team defeated the hosts, IIT (BHU) in the finals with 3-1 and secured gold with Women’s team also finishing well on the podium with Silver after their final match against NIT Rourkela.

Hockey
Hockey team fetched Bronze with 3-1 against Galgotias in their last game, Shaurya Veer and Ashwani Prabhakar made 2 and 1 goals respectively.

Our Basketball team also participated in the event. With all these winning stories and encouraging learning experiences, we wish all our players would be eager to show even more zeal in coming Inter-IIT Sports Meet and make KGP proud.
Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates all the participants and wishes them all the best!

Men’s team defeated the hosts, IIT (BHU) in the finals with 3-1 and secured gold with Women’s team also finishing well on the podium with Silver after their final match against NIT Rourkela.

Hockey
Hockey team fetched Bronze with 3-1 against Galgotias in their last game, Shauryaveer and Ashwani made 2 and 1 goals respectively.

Our Basketball team also participated in the event. With all these winning stories and encouraging learning experiences, we wish all our players would be eager to show even more zeal in coming Inter-IIT Sports Meet and make KGP proud.
Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates all the participants and wishes them all the best!

IR Cell presents you with Global Leadership Series, a unique series of interviews, discussions and guest lectures about leadership at the global stage. Today, we have with us Ranbir (Ron) Singh Gupta, a distinguished alumnus of IIT Kharagpur from the batch of 1970, B.Arch. Ron Gupta is a top-notch architect in the US with his own company based in New York. Along with his wife, Chitra, Ron created the “Ranbir and Chitra Gupta School of Infrastructure Design and Management“ (RCGSIDM), first such school of its kind in the world. Here is a short discussion on his philosophy of giving back, objectives of the RCGSIDM School and some advice for the young entrepreneurs.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mrIYXsEM11Q

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 3 new photos.
message:
After two days of splendid performances and soaring tempo,the open IIT Dramatics ended on 31st October around midnight.
The winners are-
1st Position- Patel Hall (78 points)
2nd Position- Nehru Hall (74 points)
3rd Position- LLR Hall (73 points)
Best lead actor- Nikhil Choudhary (Nehru)
Best supporting actor- Abhay Daga (LLR) and Sumit Advani (Nehru)
Best script- LLR Hall
Best sounds and lights effects- Patel Hall
Best set and costumes- Azad Hall and RK Hall.

The Judge appreciated the efforts by all the participating Halls (Patel, Nehru, Azad, RK, RP and LBS).
"Portrayal of the vast areas of themes, ranging from emotional to the ones covering social issues and the ones that tickle you- was simply mesmerising. Clearly, they've all worked very hard.", she told us. Having judged the same event last year,she shared,"The organisation, timing and of course, the plays are better than they were last year."
Dramatics, undoubtedly, is ever evolving here!

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates all the winners.

There is no gainsaying the fact that KGPians never fail to amaze the world with their skills. This time, it's Madhav Datt who is one of the 12 finalists of the world's biggest and most prestigious data science competition i.e., TEXATA Big Data Analytics World Championships 2017. And he is the only 'student' in the top 12. Rest are professionals from KPMG, RStudio, UBER etc. There were professionals, top data experts and university students all over the world showcasing their Big Data, Data Science, Machine Learning and Business Analytics skills, battling out for a spot in the finals. Madhav has surely put IIT Kharagpur on the world's map as a top competitor in such events with his exceptional performance.
The top 12 Live World Finals will be held at the University of Texas at Austin on 18th and 19th of November.
To know more about him, visit:
http://awaaziitkgp.org/ma...

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates him for his stellar performance and wishes all the best for the finals.

Microsoft teams up with professors from IIT Kharagpur towards developing their search engine 'Bing'. The aim is that it could assist users looking for subjective information and trust opinions like "How to make small talk with new friends" or "The song that defined the 80s". Their basic idea is to extract meaningful information from social media conversation to help search engines answer social list queries better by deploying artificial intelligence and machine learning. The team used multi-word hashtag from Twitter and by analysis of it, the search engine could scour social networks and detect valuable insights from public conversations using a precise algorithm to provide deeper search experiences.
Source: https://economictimes.ind...

story: The Scholars' Avenue shared IIT KGP Sports's post.
message:
The Scholars' Avenue shared IIT KGP Sports's post.

The Annual Sports Fest of IIT-BHU, Spardha, witnessed a blazing performance from the KGP Sports Contingent. With 98 students across 6 sports participating in the competition, IIT Kharagpur stood distinct and apprehended the podium in almost all the games.
The results are as follows:

Badminton (Men's - Gold Women's - Silver)
The Men’s Team fascinated the show by clubbing down IIT-BHU in the finals by 3-1 and bringing home the gold medal.
The Women’s also put up a similar performance and won the Silver medal, losing to NIT Rourkela in the finals.

Weightlifting (Silver)
In weightlifting, IIT KGP bagged the silver medal with a grand total of 20 points . IIT BHU won the gold with 22 points. We managed a gold and a silver in Under 69 Kg category, a silver and bronze in Under 77 Kg and a bronze in Under 62 Kg Category.

Volleyball : (Men's - Bronze , Women's - Bronze)
Both Men’s and Women’s Team finished third on the podium and secured the bronze medal.

Hockey (Bronze)
The Hockey Team defeated the Galgotias by 3-1 in the semifinals and finished 3rd

Football (Bronze)
The football team won the Bronze medal by smashing down their opponents, SRMCEM, by 5-0 in the last game.

The tournament proved to be a learning curve for the basketball team with plenty of positives and experience to take from their participation. Nevertheless the teams always displayed their desire to win with their positive character on the court.

IIT KGP Sports congratulates all the participants for their stupendous efforts and looks forward to an even better performance at the upcoming Inter IIT Sports Meet.

Your story. Our trophy. #Go_for_Gold.
http://www.thehindubusine...

There is a dire need to reflect on the answers we had been given at the open house in order to constantly gauge how well the execution is going on. We present to you a list of questions asked and answers given in the open house. We can also be a better judge of the quality of solutions proposed and the explanations given to us, as we read it calmly in the comfort of our room, sans any rhetoric, chanting or aggression.
Let us know if we have missed any questions or if there are any clarifications to be made.

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 2 new photos.
message:
Open IIT Chess | Results
This year, Open IIT Chess saw a see-saw battle with some bigwigs getting denied the expected points unexpectedly. The competition, held under the tutelage of Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur with the cooperation of Chess club, IIT Kharagpur, witnessed 9 rounds of intense strategies and mind boggling battles on board. The results are as follows:

Boys:
Gold - Kaustav Chakraborty
Silver - Prithwi Sinha
Bronze - Vivek Gupta

Girls:
Gold - Akshitha Saripalli
Silver - Nishtha Chandaliya
Bronze - Yogshree Choukse

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates all the winners and hopes that chess culture on the campus will see a rise in the coming days, given the recent initiatives taken by the Chess Club.

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 13 new photos — with Shourya Kumar and 7 others.
message:
To celebrate 'Patel Jayanti', Patel Hall of Residence organized a Blood Donation Camp and various competitions for the students of Kendriya Vidyalaya, IIT Kharagpur as a part of “Unity Drive”. The Blood Donation Camp was organized today in association with Calcutta National Medical College, Kolkata and it was inaugurated by Prof. Somesh Kumar, Dean of Students Affairs and Prof. Sanjib Patra, Assistant Warden, Patel Hall. The entire IIT KGP community got united to donate blood and it saw a huge participation of 80 donors. Around 80 units of blood were collected during this camp.
Competitions for students of Kendriya Vidyalaya including Quiz and Drawing/Painting Competition was organized on 28th October to promote unity among school students whose winners will be awarded on 31st October at Patel Hall of Residence while celebrating Patel Jayanti.

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 10 new photos.
message:
With an objective to bring people closer to each other on the personal level and increase interaction among themselves, Azad Hall of Residence organised a Social and Cultural night yesterday that saw the participation of over 100 first and second years along with seniors students as well. The night saw a competition between different wings that included singing, stand-up comedy, skit, instrument playing, poem reciting, mimicry etc. initiatives like this will help students because of the much-needed initiatives that our campus requires given the recent events that have taken place. These types of events are a part of Hall Culture of the campus and we urge the students community to take part in such events as much as possible whenever they are held to bring ourselves together as a community.
#ICanSave

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 10 new photos.
message:
With an objective to bring people closer to each other on the personal level and increase interaction among themselves, Azad Hall of Residence organised a Social and Cultural night yesternight that saw the participation of over 100 first and second years along with seniors students as well. The night saw a competition between different wings that included singing, stand-up comedy, skit, instrument playing, poem reciting, mimicry etc. This, for sure, is a good initiative that will help students because of the much-needed initiatives that our campus requires given the recent events that have taken place.
We hope that each and every Hall will come up with similar or new initiatives which can serve such purposes.
#ICanSave

There have been requests from several of you who could not give the WInter Workshop test today for various reasons. Keeping this in mind, we are keeping a Compensation Test this Tuesday, 31st October, at 7.00 p.m. Make sure to be there!

If you haven't registered yet you can do so here-

The Open House Session conducted yesterday ended on a quite constructive note. The session turned out to be highly interactive with active participation of students, stakeholders and administrative authorities including the Director and the Deputy Director of the institute. There was a discussion on quite a few questions and proposals regarding improvements in services of BC Roy Technology Hospital and the efficiency of Counselling Centre. The discussion involved several discrepancies on part of the authorities as well as the students regarding BCRTH and its requisite facilities involving ambulances and ICU. Overall, it was a good and interactive discussion on various prospects, where the students received satisfactory, and in some cases, unsatisfactory answers to the questions raised.

Thus, with an aim to take some major steps on priority in order to improve the Counselling Centre and medical facility standards at BC Roy Technology Hospital, Awaaz conducts a survey asking KGP community for suggestions for the same.
Please respond to the form attached below so that relevant suggestions could be passed on to the highest of the authorities as discussed the previous day.

"सुकून मिलता है दो लफ्ज़ कागज पर उतारकर,
चीख भी लेता हूँ और आवाज़ भी नहीं होती |"

कुछ इसी तरह की कविताओं और ग़ज़लों को लेकर प्रौद्योगिकी साहित्यिक समूह जल्द ही लेकर आ रहा है काव्य संध्या का चौथा संस्करण:
यदि आप अपनी कोई भी कविता प्रस्तुत करना चाहे, तो इस form को भर कर औपचारिकता पूरी करे |

https://goo.gl/forms/SNHH...

उर्दू के मशहूर शायर बशीर बद्र कहते हैं ,
"अगर फ़ुर्सत मिले पानी की तहरीरों को पढ़ लेना
हर एक दरिया हज़ारों साल का अफ़साना लिखता है |"
ऐसे ही कई अफ़सानों को अपने आप में समेटे हुई होती है " कविता " और कुछ ऐसी ही कविताओं से भरी एक शाम " काव्य संध्या " लेकर प्रौद्योगिकी साहित्यिक समूह आपके बीच आ रहे हैं ।
मंच पूरी तरह से तैयार है बस इंतज़ार है आपका, तो शीघ्र ही इस form- को भर कर औपचारिकता पूरी करें ।

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 3 new photos.
message: Yesterday, a group of professors and other staff members rallied for the "Dearness Relief Fund and implementation of 7th pay commission". As they said, they haven't got this fund from last two years. IIT Bombay, ISM (IIT) Dhanbad and many other IITs have already released this fund but they can't see any sign of IIT KGP releasing this fund anytime soon. They stated that most of the government bodies have already released this fund, even some of newly constituted bodies as well. But IIT Kharagpur hasn't released the same for its employees.

Are you still struggling to find your path in life, deciding your career, looking for opportunities? Communiqué is here with just what you need. As a part of Career Drive, We are conducting a seminar on "Non-Technical Career Opportunities after Engineering" by Mr. Vikash Goel. Mr. Vikash Goel is the Managing Director of Omnifin Solutions. Be there to pave your future and grab the chance to be part of exciting projects offered by Omnifin Solutions requiring some programming skills.
The seminar will focus on :-

1) Entrepreneurship & Consulting
2) Diversity of roles in organisations
3) Approaching various case studies
4) Strategically drafting CVs
5) Paid and certified projects on application of Artificial Intelligence

Details of the event :-

Date: 29th Oct'17
Day: Sunday
Venue: Vikramshilla, V3
Time: 5 pm onwards

#CareerDrive_2

Hey KGP, thanks for turning up in the huge numbers that you did for The Open House session with our Director, Dr. Partha Pratim Chakrabarti. It was a very long session with the conclusion leaving a few students unsatisfied with the responses of the administration but nevertheless agreeing that a constructive discussion now is what the need of the hour is.
Here is a summary of the entire event with our own viewpoints as a team given along with it.
We request all our readers, including students, alumni and the professors to give this a read and please reach out to us in case you have any points of clarification in the comments or if you have a more detailed point that you want to raise personally as a mail or a message to us.

story: Student Welfare Group (SWG)  IIT Kharagpur shared Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur's event.

message:
| Message from Student Senate|

This post is to clarify the various misunderstandings that we have been informed about (points 1-5). We also lay out our plan of action (point 6) to get our demands heard and met.

1. Incident report
It was compiled to make student community aware of the account given by the eyewitnesses, and the responses (or the lack of it) by the administration on the same. We kept everything in the raw format so that the students could judge for themselves which claims are true, or what answers are satisfactory. We encourage everyone to raise any point from that report in the Open House in case they are unsatisfied.

2. Questionnaire distribution to admin and students
The objective of the Open House is to get clear cut answers out in the open to pressing questions and queries in the students’ minds. This was the reason behind floating the questionnaire to the student community in advance. However, to prevent anyone from getting away from answering a difficult question by a simple ‘we will look into it and get back to you’, we think it is important that they receive a copy of the questions beforehand and come prepared to face the students. We will release the same copy to the students as well.

3. Selection/Filtering of questions by Senate for Open House This was the most disheartening impression held by the students communicated to us. As the Senate, we are always on the students’ side. We have been working hard to compile all questions collected by Awaaz’s and the VP’s survey. We want to finalize a repository of questions that cover different aspects of the issues at hand. We hope you can trust us enough to not tamper with the questions and let difficult ones be skipped by anyone. The major part of the session is for students to ask questions directly, a report of which will be compiled and again sent to everyone.

4. Conversation with Mr Raghuvanshi, ASP
The purpose of visiting him and sharing the conversation was to bring out a missing perspective regarding the situation. We identified his to be a unique standpoint having closely seen both incidents people have been talking about. However, we were unable to frame our interaction to portray the same intention. By no means was that document a hidden threat against protests, a way to shift blame or even an attempt to absolve the status of B.C. Roy’s facilities. We apologize for any anger or dissatisfaction caused due to our inability to recreate the conversation for you. No one can stop you to express yourself through peaceful protests. At the point when things start to escalate and lose control, the police will be bound to take actions. His statement was supposed to be a warning to students to keep things in check for their own benefit. A repeat of what happened back in 2009 can have some regretful consequences for some people, and we do not want that to happen to anyone unnecessarily.

5. Limiting the session to only B.C.R.H and Counseling Centre
To fulfil the objective of getting concrete solutions and directed answers, it is extremely necessary to keep asking questions that are on point. Diversifying the topic might lead to the focus being shifted, or people getting lost in the conversation. We will have other similar sessions in the future to tackle other issues. We hope you will show similar fervour towards them as well.

6. Action plan
The student community is filled with anger and sorrow. It is important to channel these emotions productively. We plan to use this session to put up our demands. The administration is given an ultimatum to come up with the solutions, and the plan for implementation. If we feel, as a community, that their response is inadequate, we will protest (non-violently) against the administration for a better KGP on Saturday itself. We believe this to be the best course of action at the moment to get favourable results.

| B.C. Roy Hospital Tales | Part 1
Recently, we had released a feedback form on B.C. Roy Technology Hospital and most of the responses are an eye opener regarding the current state of affairs at one and only hospital available in the campus. We feel that it's equally important for all the people to get to know about some of these experiences* that people have had with this hospital.

Experience 1:
I had an accident on my cycle which cut off a decent chunk of my toe with the nail at 7am. I was made to sit waiting for over 30 mins with no first aid provided and hence, losing blood. And when someone finally came to clean up the wound, they were harsh and gave me a lecture having disturbed their sleep.
Another time, during the vacations, I had stitches in my ear which I requested to be checked and removed when ready. The removal was postponed by almost a week saying my wound hasn't healed which resulted in my wound getting septic due to inadequate cleaning. The stitch removal process in the septic state was extremely painful and when requested for a surface anaesthetic, I was told that it was a long procedure for allowance. So, I should "MAN UP".

Experience 2:
I was suffering from viral fever and the medicines prescribed by the initial examination couldn't cure me. As it worsened, I was hospitalised after 10 days. In the hospital, I was given high dosages of antibiotic (1000 mg) along with saline drip regularly. This was the first time I was given a drip (completely unnecessary).
After 2 days, my condition worsened with my temperature reaching up to 103 F. I contacted my family doctor who clearly told me that it was impossible to cure me with the medicines I was being given. My parents arrived the very next morning and I forcefully got myself discharged and taken to my hometown. I was there given no antibiotic, just some Vicks tablet and Dabur Honitus as the infection was in my throat which the BC Roy doctors couldn't find out. I became completely fine and came back to college in 5 days.

Experience 3:
I have a disease called migraine. Once, I reached B.C. Roy with a major attack of migraine and at the same time, they were handling a critical case of some other person. I was crying like anything. No one was ready to take my complaint while I literary cried in front of them. But no one was helping me, may be due to that critical case. I didn't want doctors to pay attention towards me instead of that critical case but I wanted them to have a sufficient number of emergency doctors to treat 12,000 KGPians.

Experience 4:
During my second year, I and my friend met with an accident. We went to the hospital late night and the doctor who was on the night shift in the emergency section said this to us - "Yeh koi time hai aane ka" **Is this a proper time to come to the hospital?** Later, after getting an X-ray, I got to know that I might be having a fracture on scaphoid bone. He wanted to confirm. So, he recommended 'another' X-ray and told me to come after a week because he won't be available. Finally, I settled with having a treatment outside our campus!

A one-liner response that conveyed various things at one go was "Never been to BC Roy because of bad reviews".

*All the concerned respondents have already been asked for their consent to publish their experiences here.

message:
Continuing the thread of presenting the best of the Rangolis that KGP saw this Diwali, here's the Bronze winning Rangoli of RK Hall with the detailed description.
Theme: Life of Buddha
Detailed Description: The world today is moving towards a dark age, an age where wars would be inevitable. Also at present people are facing huge stress, pressure. Disputes and conflicts are becoming a commonplace now. Buddha, many centuries ago, has shown a path to peace. He told his followers to follow five basic rules if they want to lead a happy life and if someone wants to attain pure peace, can follow his way. By means of our rangoli, we want the people of today to learn from Buddha's life, his teachings and ways of becoming happy. As KGPians have 'peace' as their lingo, the life of a person who first attained 'peace' was shown.

"How many deaths will it take 'til he knows,
That too many people have died?"
- Bob Dylan

An eerily similar incident back in 2009 caused the resignation of the then Director and the Dean of Student Affairs among the multitude of events it resulted in. Three tragedies happened on 21st October 2017, 8 years later.

https://web.scholarsavenu...

Dear readers, we think it is imperative that facts come out as they are. As such, this post is about how B.C Roy Hospital’s negligence and casual attitude has cost a life.

Witnesses’ account on what transpired in that ambulance -
Nikhil’s serious condition got him referred to the nearest hospital capable of handling such cases - West Bank Hospital, Howrah. An ambulance left with two students with the patient along with an attendant and a special doctor, both of whom were said to be ‘the best’ B.C. Roy Hospital could provide. However, according to reports, their behavior towards the patient could only be accurately described as apathetic and cold. Nikhil’s multiple injuries and the bumpy ride sometimes led to his limbs moving to awkward positions. On bringing the doctor’s attention to this and asking if it would be appropriate to move it back to its original position, he glanced at the patient once and then looked away without giving any response. This was reportedly his attitude throughout the supercritical journey to Howrah, with two inexperienced boys having to take up the heavy responsibility of ensuring that Nikhil completes it alive. The ambulance was being guided by a police vehicle as the driver did not know the way to the hospital. He took a wrong turn into a one way road and in the attempt to get the vehicle back onto the main road, the ambulance broke down and everybody had to get down to push the vehicle to get it going, leaving Nikhil alone inside. It was during this ruckus that the IV drip to his arm (with the injections and the medicines) came out as well. While the doctor ignored this detail, the attendant tried to put the syringe back but then gave up saying ‘it is only a matter of 10 minutes until we arrive at the hospital’. It was at this point, the witnesses tell us, that Nikhil’s health started declining rapidly and the urgency of the situation started escalating. The broken down ambulance was proving to be a dead end, and they hitched a lift on a truck to reach the hospital. What was just a matter of ‘10 minutes’ became 45. He was barely holding on and within 10 minutes of trying to revive him in the hospital, he breathed his last. The official time of death recorded was signed off by a doctor, who arrived much after his death.

As is pretty clear with this account, Nikhil might have made it out alive had the ambulance, and the personnel accompanying him on behalf of the hospital were competent and proactive during the entire ordeal. It is appalling that people keep dying yet the administration refuses to take any responsibility.

message:
Continuing the thread of presenting the best of the Rangolis that KGP saw this Diwali, here's the Silver winning Rangoli of Patel Hall with the detailed description.
Theme: The Last Option?
Description: This was in the wake of recent events that happened at IIT Kharagpur. It was depicted that what a child, a student of today has to go through. He has problems that seem incomprehensible to his own people. He has questions that nobody can answer. There are obviously certain issues that a child can not discuss with his parents directly. Also, in such cases, the child hesitates to seek anybody's help. Under this situation, suicide seems to be the last option. But it isn't!
Suicide is never a solution to anything. We must understand that pushing your child to any limits is not the way he or she can grow. We must try and create an environment for every child that allows him or her to follow what he or she dreams, allow them to discover possibilities, not compare them with anyone and not treat them like a robot manifested by the so-called 'Modern World'.

story: The Scholars' Avenue added 3 new photos.
message:
There has been much distortion about the suicide of Nikhil Bhatia, and this post is an attempt to clear up the specifics of the incidents the best we can. This is the first in a series of questions to the administration about the way incidents like these have been handled and the lack of facilities to deal with mental and physical health emergencies.

In a report published by ToI, which has since been corrected online ( https://timesofindia.indi... ), Nikhil was said to have 'accidentally fallen off the terrace of LBS while playing with his friends'. On speaking to witnesses present, we were told that his bag was found beside a dustbin on the 4th floor of the hall, and that the doors to the terrace of that wing are kept locked. The wing corridor was also empty at the time of the incident, and no one was reported to have been playing around there at all. The corridor grill is such that it'll be highly unlikely for a person of his physical stature to have accidentally fallen off, especially with the platforms at the base. We were also made aware of a previous attempt by the same student a month back in VS Hall, and his FacAd being aware of his problems (as quoted in this article - https://timesofindia.indi... ).

The incident took place at around 11am on Saturday morning, when some workers and students heard a loud thud and saw a bloodied Nikhil on the cemented ground. He was immediately taken to the B.C. Roy hospital and then referred to the West Bank Hospital, the closest hospital with an ICU being in Howrah.

We pray he rests in peace now, and hope the rest of us can look around and fix the broken pieces that let people among us slip away. Most importantly, we hope that 5 deaths on campus in this year are enough to shake us out of this apathy and get the facilities working to fulfill the basic needs for a place with more than 20,000 people in it.

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 2 new photos — with Lavisha Parab and 11 others.
message:
Continuing the thread of presenting the best of the Rangolis that KGP saw this Diwali, here's the Gold winning Rangoli of SN/IG Hall with the detailed description.
Theme: Menstruation
Description: Vedic Hinduism and Pagan religion believed that the alignment of the moon and celestial bodies that is, the nakshatras, gave the female her core strength and her ability to reproduce and regenerate. Menstruation marks the birth of fertility and this rangoli tries to show this phase of a woman’s life. The upper region of rangoli depicts the universe and the celestial bodies. The moon cycle mirrors a woman’s menstrual cycle, which lasts roughly 29.5 days, just as the waxing and waning of the moon. A woman’s menstrual cycle changes from the menstruation of new growth to the ovulation of full power and blossom, to the pre-menstrual phase of harvest and degeneration, and back to menstruation of renewal again. Here you can see Venus, the Greek goddess of love, beauty, femininity, fertility and prosperity. The entire energy of the universe concentrates, forming a spiral, bestowing all its power to give women their inner strength.
The menstrual blood is sacred and self-nourishing, as you can see in the centre. These flames represent her core strength to fight her inner demons and also Indian celebrations or yagyas performed when a girl first menstruates. The lotus symbolizes the womb and water her ability to be calm and composed during tense situations. The greenery depicts her connection with Mother nature, the butterflies her freedom and flowers her beauty and elegance.
To the right is painted a picture of the harsh realities of today, because early religions never considered menstruation are unholy or impure. Whether ovulating or bleeding, struggling with pre-menstrual syndrome or conception, our bodies, energy levels, sense of self, even our abilities are constantly shifting each and every day. And yet, nobody talks about it – a taboo among more mundane and everyday topics. The myths, such as, a menstruating woman is dirty and impure, that she cannot worship, that when she touches a tree, it wilts and that can she cannot lead a normal life during that phase are baseless, for it’s not the inner you but only the biology that is changing. Let us accept that menstrual blood is pure, sacred and respect women for being blessed with the power to give birth.
As Manu from Hindu Mythology says in Manusmriti, “Yatra Naryastu Pujyante, Ramanti Tatra Devtaha, Yatraitaastu Na Pujyante, Savastatra Afalaha Kriyaha”
Which means ‘the divine are extremely happy where women are respected, but where they are not, all actions, however good and holy, are fruitless’. Let's talk about menstruation freely, not as if it's a taboo and let the flower of fertility blossom.

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 4 new photos.
message:
Just a few days ago, IIT Kharagpur​ saw best of the Rangolis on the occasion of Diwali celebrations. Though each one of those was fabulous, some of them stood apart as per the judges. And many of you didn't get a chance to come through those due to various reasons like rain or staying at home.
So, we present the Gold winning Rangoli of RP Hall.
Theme: Shiva Shakti Cha.
Description: As formerly presented, Daksha Prajapati disposed of the notion of inviting Shiva and Sati in his yaagya, but Sati been stubborn on her will to attend the yaagya, convinced Shiva to let his devotees escort her to the yaagya. Devi Sati’s incoming wasn’t welcomed at the yaagya, Daksh Prajapati spoke false in favour of her consort, insulted Lord Shiva which consequently angered Sati and she incarnated into "Aadi Parshakti" to curse Daksh Prajapati that he’ll conceive death through Shiva’s hands and she herself took samadhi at the very event. Later Shiva incarnated in form of Veerbhadra and realized the curse Daksha Prajapati was entitled to and killed him. Vishnu separated Aadi Parshakti’s corpse into 52 pieces, to ensure her soul to rest in heaven.
Decades later after the happening of this event, Aadi Shakti again took birth on earth as Parvati and worshipped Lord Shiva to impress Shiva and marry her.
SHIVA symbolises consciousness, the masculine principle. SHAKTI symbolises the feminine principle, the activating power and energy. SHAKTI (or Prakriti) means energy, power, movement, change, nature. It is the maternal principle – the provider, abundance. SHIVA (or Purusha), on the other hand, is pure consciousness – the unchanging, unlimited and unswayable observer. Purusha has no desires whatsoever; these are inherent only in Prakriti. Purusha is the empty.
As described in Shiv Purana:
एवं परस्परापेक्षा शक्तिशक्तिमतो: स्थिता।
न शिवेन विना शक्तिर्न शक्तया विना शिव:॥
Meaning, Shiva and Shakti always long for each other, neither can Shiva exist without Shakti, nor can Shakti exist without Shiva.
Only when Shiva and Shakti combine; action, movement and creation arise. Until energy is impregnated with consciousness; it is ignorant, disordered, aimless and “blind”. Energy alone can produce nothing; consciousness bestows upon it content, form and direction. Conversely, consciousness without energy is dormant power, sleeping energy, and on its own is unable to be the cause of anything. Just as Prakriti without Purusha is unable to act, and vice versa, Purusha without Prakriti is also incapable of creating anything.
Shakti is the motherly love of God that surrounds us with warmth, caring and protection. Shiva is the paternal love of God that gives us consciousness, clarity and knowledge.

Two different lights were used to depicts two different scenes in a single Rangoli. This Rangoli, under blue light, showed Shiva and under red light, showed Parvati. It was made up of 1 lakh 20 thousand pixels and included more than 360 shades of colours.

Two teams from IIT Hyderabad and IIT Bombay working together have formulated a method to kill skin cancer cells using the extract of an Indian medicinal plant Anthocephalus Cadamba combined with a near-infrared dye. The extract and the dye used together were able to kill 82-83% of cancer cells. The results were published in the International Journal of Biological Macromolecules.
Further research will be carried out on the different kinds of breast cancer in animal models.
Source: http://www.thehindu.com/s...

Call for Ag-Robotics proposal:

We invite students' proposal for robotics project. The project should target automation
or augmentation of agricultural operations. We may select multiple proposals, depending
upon clarity of plan and merit of the target design. Selected proposal with Budget within Rs. 50 k, may get quick approval and funding. For larger budgets, the selected proposals may need to be discussed with the team to justify cost associated with each component.

The proposal should contain the following:

(i) Title
(ii) Objective (Target design) (100 words)
(iii) Need and motivation behind the proposed design (max : 200 words)
(iii) Schematic diagram of the proposed design (hand-drawn would be fine)
(iv) Approach (discuss your methodology, platforms, resources needed for different aspects
of the design. (max 300 words)
(v) Team members, their earlier experience and their responsibilities in the proposed project. (include: Name, Roll, Email, Phone, Hall, Project experiences for each member)

(vi) Budget

Please submit the proposal latest by 29th of October using the following link

https://www.dropbox.com/r...

message:
Students' Alumni Cell feels proud in announcing the final dates for the 15th Annual Alumni Meet, our flagship event organized on campus. The Institute gears up for 12th-14th January, 2018, the days when the alumni will revisit their cornerstone of success. The past will rejoice in the present, old memories will be relived and new memories will be rewritten from them.

The guests of honour for this year's meet are the Batches of 1968 (Golden Jubilee), 1978 (Ruby Jubilee) and 1993 (Silver Jubilee) and Students' Alumni Cell would like to cordially invite them for the meet.

A sad and quite unfortunate incident took place today when a 5th-year student of our campus died in Kolkata after attempting a suicide and consequently, sustaining injuries. The questions were already being raised about the steps taken by the administration to curb the suicides after the campus saw 4 suicides on a trot in the campus last semester but today's incident unearths and points out towards some serious and major loopholes in the existing setup.

For the reasons understandable, we will not be mentioning any names here.

As per the information that we have got, the attempt of committing suicide took place around 10:50 am today in LBS hall when the student jumped from the 4th floor of the hall building. He was not a resident of LBS hall of residence. As soon as people found out, they called the ambulance. So, he was soon taken to the hospital in the ambulance. On seeing the student’s condition, BC Roy Technology Hospital referred him to Kolkata. The ambulance left the campus around 12:10 pm in the noon after completing all the paperwork where the student accompanying him was asked to get the signatures of the warden and a lot of other paperwork which almost took 40 minutes. In the meantime, there was a problem with the lights of the ambulance. So, another ambulance was called. Also, there was another delay of almost 10-15 minutes as the attendant was out of reach. During this time, as the pulse was near zero, the hospital people gave some injections and initial treatment to stabilize his pulse to 40-50. If they wouldn't have done it then he might have passed away right then. So it took nearly 25-30 minutes to stabilize the pulse. And finally, the ambulance left the campus around 12:10 pm. The ambulance was accompanied by 2 escorts to Kolkata. Two of his friends with the Hall Manager, two attendants, and the doctor were in the ambulance. The driver misjudged a path to the hospital which further worsened the situation. As told by the accompanying students, the behavior of the hospital staff raised a lot of questions as they were not very supportive. The oxygen masks and the drips got mishandled and they were not able to fix it properly again. Prior to some 15-20 minutes before reaching the hospital, ambulance broke down and they were left in a miserable condition. The students tried to get another vehicle. After a while and a lot of efforts of the students and the policeman accompanying them, a Tata Ace owner agreed to take them to the hospital. As soon as the additional SP and the Director got this news, they informed the hospital at the other end and an ambulance was started in a reverse way to attend the case, but as the ambulance came to the spot, they saw nobody and they got information that they have left using some other source. Midway, the tank of this vehicle got emptied. So, they got it refilled. After all this delay, they reached the hospital couple of minutes after 2:30 pm. And the doctors there, after some time, declared him dead.

The reasons for the attempt of suicide, the role of administration, faculties, management, counseling center will be raised later after getting all the details. But, the main question that arises here is the ability of the BC Roy Hospital in one of the premier institutes of the country to handle 12,000 students and thousands of people residing in Kharagpur, when it does not even have basic amenities at its disposal and the behavior of the staff coming into question. Can't we have a fully functional hospital as it would serve more than 25000 people!

We are not blaming anyone for the incident but some major steps need to be taken on priority in order to improve the medical facility standards at BC Roy Hospital as this is not the first time that such events have happened. There have been some major events in the past as well. Referring to Kolkata if any major injury takes place is not a solution.

And if this continues without any improvement, the chances of such mishaps happening again are pretty high. It's high time it is made a priority.

Please respond to the form attached below so that this serious issue can be raised to the highest of the authorities.

|A reality check|
A sad and quite unfortunate incident took place today when a 5th-year student of our campus died in Kolkata after attempting a suicide and consequently, sustaining injuries. The questions were already being raised about the steps taken by the administration to curb the suicides after the campus saw 4 suicides on a trot in the campus last semester but the timeline of today's incident unearths and points out towards some serious and major loopholes in the existing setup.

For the reasons understandable, we will not be mentioning any names here.

As per the information that we have got, the attempt of committing suicide took place around 10:50 am today in LBS hall when the student jumped from the 4th floor of the hall building. But the ambulance left the campus around 12:10 pm in the noon after completing all the paperwork where the student accompanying him was asked to get the signatures of the warden and a lot of other paperwork which almost took 40 minutes. In the meantime, there was a problem with the lights of the ambulance. So, another ambulance was called. Also, there was another delay of almost 10-15 minutes as the attendant was out of reach. And finally, after much delay, the ambulance left the campus around 12:10 pm. The ambulance was accompanied by 2 escorts to Kolkata. Two of his friends with the Hall Manager, two attendants, and the doctor were in the ambulance. The driver misjudged a path to the hospital which further worsened the situation. As told by the accompanying students, the behavior of the hospital staff raised a lot of questions as they were not very supportive. The oxygen masks and the drips got mishandled and they were not able to fix it properly again. As soon as the additional SP and the Director got this news, they informed the hospital at the other end and an ambulance was started in a reverse way to attend the case, but as the ambulance came to the spot, they saw nobody and they got information that they have left using some other source. These clearly show the lack of communication. Midway, the tank of this vehicle got emptied. So, they got it refilled. After all this delay, they reached the hospital couple of minutes after 2:30 pm. And the doctors there, after some time, declared him dead.

The reasons for the attempt of suicide, the role of administration, faculties, management, counseling center will be raised later after getting all the details. And what's the cost of a person’s life here? We are not blaming anyone for the incident but some major steps need to be taken on priority in order to improve the medical facility standards at BC Roy Hospital as this is not the first time that such events have happened. There have been some major events in the past as well.

And if this continues without any improvement, the chances of such mishaps happening again are pretty high. It's high time it is made a priority.

Inshorts, Swiggy, Runnr, TVF- we all have heard about these Startups who are currently making it big in the Indian Startup Ecosystem. The people who have shaped these startups were once a part of the KGP Family, and they hustled everyday in order to turn their idea into a reality. They believed to be the game changers and decided to leave their secure jobs to face the odd struggles that every new entrant faces.
But lately, IIT Kharagpur has seen a surprising drop in the number of operational startups and for the same reason, we want you to take this survey. This will help us to analyse different reasons why students are not starting up and the problems that the current start-up cofounders are facing in the campus. Ultimately, we will come up with some solutions that will surely have an impact on the current scenario.

Yet another gloomy day

Amongst the persisting dark walls, we must not close our eyes to the lighted windows. Life certainly doesn't go on as per our expectations. Yes, there are times when we hit the rock bottom and feel as if all the doors are closed, ending everything for us. But hang on! That's not the true and complete picture. It might momentarily occur to you that everything has gone dark. But in the long run, remember that every night sees its dawn. Nothing is permanent and neither are the adverse times.
If we stick around those who struggle to find flickers of hope, we might help them end up lighting a flame of their own.
Life gives hope and probability of happiness in future, Death kills them all.
Hold on and let's help others in the same!
Here are some lines by Swami Vivekananda:

HOLD ON YET A WHILE, BRAVE-HEART
If the sun by the cloud is hidden a bit,
If the welkin shows but gloom,
Still hold on yet a while, brave heart,
The victory is sure to come.

No winter was but summer came behind,
Each hollow crests the wave,
They push each other in light and shade;
Be steady then and brave.

The duties of life are sore indeed,
And its pleasures fleeting, vain,
The goal so shadowy seems and dim,
Yet plod on through the dark, brave heart,
With all thy might and main.

Not a work will be lost, no struggle vain,
Though hopes be blighted, powers gone;
Of thy loins shall come the heirs to all,
Then hold on yet a while, brave soul,
No good is ever undone.

Though the good and the wise in life are few,
Yet theirs are the reins to lead,
The masses know but late the worth;
Heed none and gently guide.

With thee are those who see afar,
With thee is the Lord of might,
All blessings pour on thee, great soul,
To thee may all come right!

IIT Kharagpur is stepping ahead to shape up their Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) initiatives by partnering with corporate houses and NGOs. The institute has done many research works, published them and obtained the patent for the same, and now it's time to implement those efforts for the benefits of the society, as stated by Prof. Siddartha Mukhopadhyay, Dean of Alumni Affairs and International Relations, IIT Kharagpur. The institute is looking forward to collaborating with industries from Germany and France working in India for their CSR initiatives. Corporate groups and NGOs are already excited about the potential when a technology giant collaborates with an NGO for the welfare of society. The Shrachi group has already shown interest to tie-up with IIT Kharagpur for its WASH (Water, Sanitation, Hygiene) project. More than 50% of the projects are presently active or ready to be operational in the institute which is aligned with the CSR strategies of different companies, an IIT Kharagpur spokesperson said.
To take forward this idea, Rajiv Gandhi School of Intellectual Property Law, IIT Kharagpur is taking a remarkable step by organising a short-term course on Corporate Governance towards Corporate Social Responsibility. This course is open to all faculties from Universities or the institute or interested people from the industry and other organizations. The course is scheduled to be held from 27th November to 2nd December 2017, and the last date for applying to the course is 8th November 2017.
Here is the link to the application: https://goo.gl/fQJBgV
Source: 1. http://www.jagranjosh.com...
2. http://www.livelaw.in/sho...

Hello All,
Due to rain, Illumination result stands cancelled but we appreciate the efforts of all the halls which put up such a great show even after unfortunate hindrances

We witnessed many beautiful Rangolis and the result is as follows:
1st Prize: SN/IG and RP
2nd Prize: Patel and JCB
3rd Prize: RK

Our Heartiest Congratulations to all the winners.

Results | Illumination and Rangoli 2017
Continuing the unique tradition of celebrating Diwali with 'Illumination', KGPians have today presented such an extraordinary example of resilience and perseverance that even rain gods weren't able to flinch their indomitable will (read tempo) of the students. Students with full zeal and enthusiasm, drenching in rain but still making every possible effort to light even last of the diyas was certainly a sight to applaud. Though each and every hall showcased best of the Rangolis and Illumination, still the results are as follows:

Rangoli:
Gold - RP Hall and SN/IG Hall
Silver - Patel Hall and JCB Hall
Bronze - RK Hall

Illumination:
The judges felt that it would be unfair to judge the Illuminations because of the fact that some of the halls' illumination faced heavy downpour at the time of judging and it certainly made the illumination competition heavily dependent on the timing of the rain. As per the judges, there wasn't very much scope of judging the Illuminations as some of the halls' weren't able to light their illu, all due to untimely rain. Therefore, results for the Illumination category haven't been declared.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates each and every member of the KGP community who, despite the adversities, made this celebration a grand success!

story: Pushpa Agrawal added a new photo to Student Welfare Group (SWG)  IIT Kharagpur's Timeline.

message:
Illumination: The Light in Kgp's Night
As the entire nation is gearing up for one of the most awaited festive moments of the year ‘Diwali’, the students at IIT KGP are pouring their heart out for the preparation of their own unique way of celebrating Diwali, the tradition which they call ‘Illumination’ or just ‘Illu’. For KGP, Illu is Diwali and Diwali is Illu. For the freshers who will be going to witness this trademark celebration of Diwali for the first time, they must be feeling intrigued when they find the air buzzing with ‘illu’. They must be having such questions in their mind like what is it? What’s so special about it? What for our seniors are working so hard? is that effort worth it? And all. As the campus media body of IIT KGP, Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur feels that the tale of this unique tradition must be passed on to the newcomers. So, here is this article on Illumination to let the world know about this masterpiece of KGP students where technology meets tradition.
http://awaaziitkgp.org/il...

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 12 new photos.
message:
Illumination with Cubism! Yes, you read that right. Students of the Department of Architecture & Regional Planning - IIT Kharagpur did a project in the course of Basic Design given by Prof. Joy Sen which was based on cubism that meant using linear lines and shapes.
The first year batch was divided into nine groups, each having four members. Each team had to make a model with cubes made with mount boards. On some cubes, some fenestrations or patterned holes were made so that light from the four bulbs inside the model can come out. Each model had about 36-46 cubes of 10 cm sides which were joined to form the Illumination.
The project was supervised by Teaching Assistants Mr. Deepanjan Saha and Ms. Vidhu Vinod Bhushan.

We appreciate this unique and monumental effort of the students and believe that it will take the 'Illumination' culture to new heights!

story: Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS added 4 new photos.
message:
Recently, we conducted a workshop at Nalanda, where we taught students the importance of Version Control System, and the usage of Git and Github. We also taught how to contribute to someone else's projects.

To revise the workshop:
1. Introduction to linux command line - Udacity ( https://in.udacity.com/co... )
2. Git and GitHub - Udacity ( https://in.udacity.com/co... )

To learn more than was taught in the workshop specifically about viewing older versions, modifying histories and many more tools like that:
1. Git atlassian tutorial ( https://www.atlassian.com... )
2. Git-scm ( https://git-scm.com/book/... )
3. Git Interactive Practice( https://learngitbranching... /)

Also, here are a few glimpses from the workshop!

Technology Students' Gymkhana, IIT Kharagpur shared Hult Prize At IIT Kharagpur's post.

**IMPORTANT NOTICE**
Hello everyone!
The introductory seminar organized on 12th of October saw entrepreneurial enthusiasts turn up in large numbers despite the internship and placement tests happening at the same time.
There have been some changes to the proceedings of the different rounds of Hult Prize this year from what was told in the seminar. In the words of the Director Hult Prize India, "There is a double opportunity from this year. Each campus winner goes to Regional Finals in March. One winner from each Regional Finals goes to the London accelerator. The India teams that are not the winners at Regional Finals, will have a National Finals in April-May. The National winner will also go to London accelerator. In addition, the Jury at India National Finals will include investors and industry experts bringing in, the potential for investment in ideas they like, irrespective of winning."
There is another opportunity for you guys this year! Apply soon on the portal
hultprizeat.com/iitkharag...
#HP18

Prof. Subhasish Dey, Professor at the Department of Civil Engineering has been elected as a Fellow of the Indian National Science Academy (INSA). The Indian National Science Academy (INSA) is the apex body of Indian scientists representing all branches of science and technology. The Academy consists of Foundation fellows, Fellows (FNA) and Foreign Fellows.

He completed his Ph.D. from IIT Kharagpur in 1992 and joined the institute as Assistant Professor in 1998. Prof. Dey has contributed in developing fundamental theories and solution methodologies of various problems on hydrodynamics. He also holds the Adjunct Professor position in the Physics and Applied Mathematics Unit at Indian Statistical Institute Kolkata (2014–19) and the Distinguished Visiting Professor of Tsinghua University position in the Department of Hydraulic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China (2016–18).

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur heartily congratulates our professor and wishes him all the best for future endeavours!

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 4 new photos.
message:
Badminton players of IIT Kharagpur have made us all proud by securing Silver in the recently concluded Annual Sports Festival of IIT Kanpur i.e., Udghosh, IIT Kanpur. IIT Kharagpur's badminton team consisted of Sayantan Sarkar, Sumit Singh, Abhishek Singhal, Saket Thavanani and Punit Jain.
After topping their pool by winning both the matches, they steamrolled their opponents in pre-quarters and quarters. Then they got past over N.I.E.C. Delhi in semi-final to face host IIT Kanpur in the final. With their valiant efforts, they finally secured the silver medal and carved out a niche of their own!
Also, our Squash team finished fourth and in the process, beat IIT Roorkee in the quarter-finals! Squash team members include Manish Datta, Harsh Saraf and Apurv Dave.
IIT KGP had sent teams for only these two sports. We hope that now more teams will be sent to participate in such competitions and show their mettle.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates all the winners!

Blockchain is the world’s leading software for digital assets, but it’s possible applications are far wider. The technology emphasizes on encrypting the data and disintermediating several factors of various industries like education industry, preventing fraudulence and impersonation. The applications can be further extended up to risk management, maintaining immutable and transparent records, gaming and anything else one can think of.
Kshitij, IIT Kharagpur in association with IBM India University Relations presents Blockchain Hackathon, which provides you an unparalleled opportunity to solve real world problems using the concepts of Blockchain.

Register at www.ktj.in/#ktj/Events -> IBM Blockchain Hackathon -> Blockchain Hackathon

With many things passing by us rapidly and a huge inflow of information, there are many a things that goes around ourselves but we either fail to notice them or don't give the kind of attention they deserve! The National Digital Library (NDL) project, the biggest online repository of its own kind, is surely one of them.
The National Digital Library of India, hosted by IIT Kharagpur and sponsored by the Ministry of Human Resource Development, is a single window portal to integrate the digital repositories of India. With the NDL app for Android and website, users can read over 7.2 million books in 70 different languages.
Give it a read to know more about it.
http://awaaziitkgp.org/nd...

Student Welfare Group (SWG) IIT Kharagpur pays tribute to our former president Dr. APJ Abdul Kalam, the Missile Man of India on his 86th birth anniversary. He may not be with us today but he will always remain immortal in our hearts by inspiring us

Quizzers from IIT Kharagpur have again shown their mettle and have continued the impressive performance they had shown so far. Team consisting of Abhimanyu Bharade and Piyush Kedia have won the Kolkata regionals of TAPMI Quiz on The Beach - one of India's biggest campus quiz competitions. With this win, they have cemented their place in the semifinals. The regionals took place on 8th of October.
Also, the team of Piyush Kedia, Shreyans Sadangi and Amit Kumar Ram, who had qualified for finals of the Sweden India Nobel Memorial Quiz, put up an impressive performance out there and made us all proud. They had won the Kolkata regionals of the same.
Earlier, the team of Harsh Agarwal and Shubham Kumar had made a mark of their own and stood 4th in one of the most coveted quiz competitions i.e., 'Tata Crucible - The Business Quiz'
We hope that quizzers of IIT Kharagpur will keep up their run of impressive performances. We would also like to thank to IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club for nurturing quizzing talents.

We congratulate all of them and wish them all the best!

Hola Freshers,
How many times have you thought of giving suggestions and changing things for better? Your opinions matter a lot and so does your feedback. You must be having a lot of pent up thoughts and feelings about your first encounter with the KGP life- "The Induction Programme".
It was an ambitious programme and the first of its own kind in the institute’s recent history on the part of the administration to make the freshers fall in love with the KGP life. Here we invite you to opine and provide the necessary feedback regarding the induction programme via this short and concise form. One minute of yours invested for this purpose is surely going to help the administration design the programme in a better way next year for the betterment of your future prospective juniors. This one minute of yours is gonna be worth it. Won’t it?
Why to wait? Fill it up: https://docs.google.com/f...

In case, you are wondering about the previous form regarding the need of shops and basic amenities in our campus, we will be releasing its analysis soon. Stay tuned!

Bitcoin is different than any currency you’ve used before, so it's very important to understand some key points. Unlike government issued money that can be inflated at will, the supply of Bitcoin is mathematically limited to twenty one million bitcoins and that can never be changed.
In our series of "Celebrating the Unconventional", Mr. Sharan Nair(VP, Unocoin) will share the technological, social & economic aspects of Bitcoin & the reasons why it can possibly replace the currencies in our pockets!
Catch him Live at Kalidas Auditorium on 15th October during EAD Kharagpur!
